clean_content:
Definition / general

* Localized collection of acute inflammation and edematous granulation tissue on the gingiva, which represents the intraoral opening of a draining odontogenic (dental) infection

Essential features

* Reactive soft tissue swelling of the gingiva* By definition, must be associated with draining dental abscess / infection (periapical or periodontal fistula)* Similar to pyogenic granuloma but contains linear tracks or accumulations of neutrophils* Must treat the source of infection, since surgical removal of the parulis alone likely will lead to recurrence

Terminology

* Gum boil* Dental fistulous tract / dental fistula* Dental abscess with sinus tract

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [K04.6](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K04-/K04.6) - periapical abscess with sinus

Sites

* Exclusively occurs on the gingiva; attached or unattached gingiva

Etiology

* Associated with dental infection
  + Pulpal necrosis, abscess ([Eur Endod J 2020;5:54](32766513))+ Infection associated with an untreated dental cavity+ Infection surrounding dental implant, embedded foreign material or other oral prosthesis

Clinical features

* Smooth and sometimes lobulated exophytic polypoid lesion on the gingiva* Yellow, red or pink (when fibrosed) in color ([Case Rep Dent 2018;2018:4850901](29967701))* Often fluctuant* Light pressure may reveal drainage of purulent exudate

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis is most often made upon clinical evaluation of fluctuant / draining gingival nodule associated with adjacent dental infection; histopathologic confirmation is useful but may not be needed* Pulpal necrosis is evaluated with electric pulp testing or thermal evaluation in combination with radiographic correlation* Intraoral sinus track can be traced with gutta percha to help confirm etiologic origin ([J Clin Diagn Res 2013;7:2392](24298540))

Radiology description

* Parulides may be accompanied by an ill or well defined radiolucency at or around the apex of a nonvital tooth ([Eur Endod J 2020;5:54](32766513))

Radiology images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Periapical radiolucency](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith01.jpg)

Periapical radiolucency

Case reports

* 40 year old woman with multiple parulides (intraoral draining sinus tracts) all associated with a single necrotic tooth ([J Clin Diagn Res 2013;7:2392](24298540))* 53 year old woman with parulis forming around dental implant ([J Oral Implantol 2016;42:505](27455359))* 59 year old man presents with a large exophytic mass of the gingiva adjacent to a necrotic tooth ([Case Rep Dent 2018;2018:4850901](29967701))

Treatment

* While the gingival nodule may be removed surgically, the nodule will recur without effective treatment of the underlying associated infection (e.g., root canal therapy, dental extraction, etc.) ([Eur Endod J 2020;5:54](32766513))* Antibiotics not indicated unless systemic spread is present ([Fertil Steril 1986;45:75](3080347))

Clinical images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Fluctuant gingival nodules](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith02.jpg)

Fluctuant gingival nodules

[![Yellow gingival nodule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith03.jpg)

Yellow gingival nodule

Gross description

* Tan / gray / brown nodule that often collapses upon sectioning and contains yellow exudate

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Nodule or collapsed nodule surfaced by keratinized squamous epithelium and comprised of edematous granulation tissue ([World J Clin Cases 2015;3:779](26380825))* Collections or linear tracts of neutrophils are present and often extend to the base of the specimen

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Exophytic nodule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith04.jpg)

Exophytic nodule

[![Loose, inflamed mesenchymal stroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith05.jpg)

Loose, inflamed mesenchymal stroma

[![Dense collections of neutrophils](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityparulishousleysmith06.jpg)

Dense collections of neutrophils

Virtual slides

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityparulisiusm01.png)](https://vmicro.iusm.iu.edu/virtual_dent/parulis.html)

Subacutely inflamed nodule

Videos

Etiology and treatment of a dental fistulous tract / parulis

Tracing a dental fistulous tract with gutta percha

Sample pathology report

* Gingiva, excisional biopsy:
  + Granulation tissue with linear tracts of neutrophils (see comment)+ Comment: When combined with the clinical information, the histomorphology is compatible with a parulis (draining fistulous tract).

Differential diagnosis

* Histopathologic:
  + [Pyogenic granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypyogenicgranuloma.html):
    - May be histopathologically identical / similar, although parulis tends to demonstrate dense accumulations or linear tracts of neutrophils that may extend to the base of the specimen- Clinical correlation is vital in the differentiation of the two entities- Distinguishing pyogenic granuloma from parulis is essential for appropriate treatment- Local excision of the polypoid lesion is sufficient for pyogenic granuloma- Parulides require treatment of the underlying infection to prevent recurrence* Clinical:
    + Clinical differential diagnosis for a red, yellow or pink nodule on the gingiva is exhaustive and may include [pyogenic granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypyogenicgranuloma.html), [peripheral giant cell granuloma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralgiantcellgranuloma.html), [peripheral ossifying fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityperipheralossifyingfibroma.html), [peripheral odontogenic fibroma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaodontogenicfibroma.html), **localized accumulation of dermal filler**, [metastatic disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillametstojaw.html) or **other malignant or benign tumors** ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:4](30693460), [World J Clin Cases 2015;3:779](26380825), [Head Neck Pathol 2013;7:241](23526034))
      - Identification of a soft tissue gingival nodule, in combination with underlying dental infection, favors diagnosis of parulis- Excisional biopsy may be used to confirm diagnosis

Additional references

* [Neville: Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology, 4th Edition, 2015](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1455770523/pathologyoutl-20)
